text:
(1)
Washington Square Park, the central and northeastern part, seen from Washington Square West.
In the right center is the new comfort station, which early in 1928 replaced the old wooden one. In the center is the fountain, used as a children's swimming pool. On the farther side of the drive is the statue of Garibaldi, erected around 1890.
August, 1935.

P. L. Sperr.

(2)
The same, showing the buildings on either side of the northeastern corner. Between the old houses on Washington Square North, and the new New York University building (about 1900) on Washington Square East, rises a new apartment building at 1 University Place, built in 1929. In the left foreground is the Washington Arch in the permanent form erected after the Washington Centennial of 1889.
August, 1935.

P. L. Sperr.
title: Manhattan: Washington Square West - 6th Avenue

title: Manhattan: Washington Square West - 6th Avenue

text:
Washington Square South (West 4th Street), east from 4th Stree
between 6th avenue and Macdougal Street.
The Washington Square Methodist Episcopal Church is in the for ground, at 135 West 4th Street. The house at the corner of Street and Washington Square West is shortly to be replaced an apartment building. The Judson tower is between Sullivan Thompson Streets. Across the park, on Washington Square East are the buildings belonging to New York University.
April 6, 1928.
P. L. Sperr.
title: Manhattan: Washington Square South - 6th Avenue

text:
Don Quixote Fountain
Holley Chambers, Washington Square

Philip Hug.
Sept. 16, 1947
title: Manhattan: Washington Square West - 6th Avenue
